awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: Adaptive Learning for Multivariate Calibration with Big Data Attributes
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program in the Chemistry Division, and partial co-funding from the Office of Investigative and Forensic Sciences in the National Institute of Justice, Professor John Kalivas and his group at Idaho State University are developing new methods of data analysis with the target of solving complex calibration problems. Calibration is a multidisciplinary problem.  In chemistry it involves forming a mathematical relationship between measured electronic signals derived from instrumental measurements and information of interest in a sample, such as the nitrogen content of plant leaves, percent fat in beef, or the blood glucose level. With the growth of the amount of generated and shared data, there is a need for a paradigm shift in calibration methods. The Kalivas group is devising means to exploit historical calibration data to improve the utility of new chemical measurements. A strategic feature of the approach is the development of new mathematical tools enabling adaptation of field-based measurements to new conditions and sample types without complex laboratory analyses, thereby reducing analysis time and costs. Through participation in this work, undergraduates from Idaho State University are learning state-of-the-art calibration methods and becoming proficient at scientific research, including dissemination. Because of the multidisciplinary nature of the project, outcomes directly benefit industry and society with efficient algorithms for rapid and accurate analysis of samples. 

This project exploits the increasing availability of spectral databases to develop completely new computational processes and accompany algorithms to address the growing need for improved and simplified multivariate calibration. The fundamentals of the inherent chemical and physical molecular interactions responsible for the measured signal are considered along with instrument-specific issues (conditions) to create new self- and cross-modeling data mining tools. Unlike conventional global and local modeling, the method does not require optimization of any tuning parameters. Additionally, reference values are not needed for target sample conditions; the method is therefore considered to be semi-supervised learning. A key goal of the project is to advance multivariate calibration to a "big-data" level, developing efficient algorithms to reveal useful information. Using reference databases, the data-mining algorithms identify samples best matrix-matched to new samples (one or many). Results from this project will advance multivariate calibration in a range of applications, including process analytical technology for the pharmaceutical and chemical industries, environmental and agriculture monitoring, and medical diagnostics. With the improvements contributed by this project, these fields will be better able to form and sustain calibrations on site, removing the need for complex chemical analysis. All developed algorithms will be posted to the Kalivas web site, allowing free access to potential users.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantitative chemical analysis (the amount of a substance (analyte) in a mixture) by calibration is concerned with forming a mathematical relationship (model) between instrumental signals (measurements) and analyte amount information. The mathematical model is formed using a set of calibration samples with known analyte quantities and measured signals. The model is then used to predict analyte values in new target samples. For example, the amount of fat or protein (two analytes) present in ground pork samples by calibrating pork samples against near infrared (NIR) spectra. However, once a model is formed for an existing set of sample and measurement conditions, this original model quickly becomes non-usable because target sample compositions and/or measuring instruments deviate from the original calibration conditions. For example, soil samples from a new geographical location or target samples measured in the field with a handheld device and the calibration was made in the laboratory with a benchtop instrument. There are an abundance of chemical and physical reasons for domain shifts and the all-inclusive term used here is “matrix effects.” Matrix effects are hidden in each sample and are sample-wise unique directing domain shifts.

Machine learning solutions to this universal problem are categorized as “domain adaptation” where calibration domain-based models are adapted to new target domains. The project focus was two approaches. One is local modeling and the other is model updating.

Regardless of the local modeling strategy, the objective is to thoroughly search (data mine) a library of reference calibration samples to pinpoint samples best matrix matched to new sample conditions. Calibration samples matched to the target sample are used to form the model and only predict analyte amount in that particular sample.

The primary project outcome that overcomes other algorithm failures is to guarantee the selected calibration samples are matrix matched to the specific target sample. To accomplish this task, the physicochemical responsive integrated similarity measure (PRISM) algorithm was formulated. It is based on the ability to assess library and target sample unknown matrix effects. PRISM is a general purpose measure and was also used for outlier detection, classification, and other situations requiring similarity assessment such as forensic scientists assessing similarities between reference samples and collected evidence.

The local modeling project approach incorporates a PRISM like process and is named local adaptive fusion regression (LAFR). The LAFR program was applied to several NIR spectral data sets such as the protein or fat content in ground pork. Libraries ranged in size from 500 to 4000 sample spectra. Ultimately, LAFR was applied to a soil data set containing over 100,000 sample spectra across the contiguous United States. Regardless of the data set size, given any target spectrum relative to the particular library data base, e.g., a target soil NIR spectrum from any location in the United States, the LAFR algorithm identifies a small set of training samples matrix matched to the target sample spectrum including closely bracketing the unknown target analyte amount.

In model updating, the objective is to augment a set of target domain samples to a general-purpose calibration sample set spanning a range of sample dependent matrix effects. By default, the original model is updated to now include target matrix effects thereby accurately predicting target domain analyte amounts.

Model updating methods typically require optimization of two or more numerical adjustable parameters (tuning parameters) and hence, thousands of models can be formed and model selection has limited the utility of model updating. Another key project outcome was the autonomous computer model selection algorithm named model diversity prediction similarity (MDPS). This algorithm successfully selects accurately predicting models with up to three tuning parameters.

Armed with MDPS, an approach to model updating was developed based on a local modeling emphasis and is named null augmented regression constant analyte (NARCA). Since multiple spectra can be easily measured on each new target sample, these spectra would all represent the same analyte amount for the particular sample. A set of repeat spectra for one target sample are augmented to the general-purpose original calibration domain samples and with MDPS, the model is updated to that one target sample.

The research was accomplished by five undergraduates. The project generated three papers with two more currently in preparation, 21 regional, national, and international meeting presentations, one pending patent, and four algorithms. All project outcomes are co-authored by undergraduates and eleven of the presentations were by undergraduates.

In summary, the project advanced calibration for multiple disciplines. Thus, all parts of society using products and services based on calibration methodologies are directly affected. For example, determining the freshness of fish or other meat products are important to the consumer. Four foundation forming algorithms were developed (PRISM, LAFR, MDPS, and NARCA) and are available for public use. With these algorithms, the future of hand-held devices has significantly improved including smart phone developments.
